Authors:
Margaret L Ellis, Kirk D Broders, Pierce A Paul, Anne E
Dorrance
Title:
Two new species of Pythium, P. schmitthennerii and P. selbii
pathogens of corn and soybean in Ohio
Abstract:
Two new species of Pythium which are pathogens of corn and
soybean in Ohio are described. Pythium schmitthennerii sp. nov. and
Pythium selbii sp. nov. both have morphological and sequence
characteristics that place them in Clade E1 of the genus Pythium.
Morphology and sequence analysis of the ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 region of the
rDNA of these species was different from previously described species.
The ITS region of Pythium schmitthennerii was 99.9% similar to P.
acrogynum and 99.8% similar to P. hypogynum, and all three species are
characterized by globose to limoniform sporangia and plerotic oospores.
Pythium schmitthennerii has mostly diclinous antheridia cells, compared
to the strictly hypogenous antheridial cells of P. acrogynum and P.
hypogynum. The temperature range for growth of P. schmitthennerii is
below 4 C to 32 C, and the optimum growth range is 18-25 C compared to
31-34 C for P. hypogynum, none has been reported for P. acrogynum. The
ITS region of P. selbii was 97.1 % similar to P. longandrum and 97.5%
similar to P. longisporangium, and all three species are characterized
by globose sporangia, mostly plerotic oospores, with one to two oospores
per oogonium, and hypogenous or monoclinous antheridial cells. The
temperature range for growth of P. selbii is below 4 to 32 C, with an
optimum range of 18-25 C. These new species were widely dispersed
throughout the soybean and corn producing regions in Ohio, making their
characterization critical for managing the Pythium complex that causes
seedling and root rot disease in Ohio soybean and corn fields.
